features: Sonett has been a pioneer in natural laundry detergents and cleaners since 1977. Sonett’s mission is to make laundry soaps and cleaning products that are harmonious and revitalizing to water and the environment. Germany's most trusted household cleaning brand.
Particularly important for babies’ woollen nappy pants which, due to the natural wool-wax content, collect the dampness from the diaper while still remaining permeable to air.
Returns the natural elasticity to woolen fabrics.
Fragrance of essential lavender oil made from certified organic cultivation.
Never tested on animals. No enzymes, petrochemical raw materials or nanotechnology. Certified by Eco-guarantie, Vegan Society, EcoControl.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 12, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Very nice product for woolen items/container a bit difficult to manage
reviews.reviewText: Sonett Organic Wool Care has been a wonderful product for my merino wool shirts and socks. It can seem like an expensive product, but as it turns out, just a very small amount is needed for a full tub of hand-washable woolen items. My only not so positive comment concerns the container. The plastic of this container is extra heavy duty, and very thick.-sided. I'm a strong handed person. I have no physical limitations, and this container gives me a hard time. If my hands are wet, which they are likely to be, from filling a basin with water, I can't manage this at all. The squeezer thing (the nozzle) is very resistant to pressure, so I find it necessary to dry both of my hands, before holding the container against the side of the basin, to release a bit of the product.I can recommend this product. It does restore softness and sheen to merino wool clothing items. Removes any itchiness that has been developing. Will purchase again.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 3, 2024
reviews.reviewText: Used this on a vintage wool military surplus blanket and it worked beautifully. It is softer and less stiff now.

reviews.reviewText: I used this on a scarf that someone had washed with Tide and after two washes came back like new

reviews.reviewText: Doesn't work to return the elasticity and texture of my wool clothe. I'm so upset

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 16, 2023
reviews.reviewText: I had a high hope of relaxing my favorite wool sweater that I accidentally put in the washer and dryer. I even tried multiple times. Smells nice and feels soft.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 4, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Does the sweater fit but smaller?
reviews.reviewText: I used 1-2 Tablespoons because I looked at the wrong instructions, added hot water to dissolve, then look warm water to fill a small basin. Trying with sweaters that fit but are smaller from bring laundered carefully. (Love the washable wool sweaters, but back to the others…). They appear to be softer, stretchier and fitting better. I think every sweater should be measured when first bought, so the size differential can be seen clearly. One very wide sweater, we hitch went in the reused water, lanolin mix, has sleeves that have not been made wearable! I may take the sleeves off. Just do a few per day. Who needs wet towels everywhere. I dried them on a hangar, which may have changed the outcome. I recommend this since I have nothing else. Buying lanolin and making your own would be interesting, because there is this dissolving part anyways.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 8, 2023
reviews.reviewText: Helped mellow the scratchiness of wool kimono fabric, though doesn't erase completely.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 5, 2022
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Works in the washing machine with my handmade wool sweaters
reviews.reviewText: I bought nine of the Aran Island hand knit merino wool sweaters last year. The tag says dry cleaning recommended, or hand wash. I hate the chemicals left in dry cleaned items, and trying to hand wash these sweaters is almost impossible. They are so thick and heavy, it's like trying to hand wash a blanket. I have a washing machine with a super delicate cycle that has worked great on cashmere sweaters, so I decided to try it with these Aran sweaters. I used an oversized lingerie bag, cold water right out of the tap (about 45 degrees) and filled the machine about 3/4 full. It only agitates for seven seconds, and then stops for seven seconds. I did an extra rinse and then put them in the dryer on Air only for five minutes. Hung them on a sweater drying rack, and shaped it back to its original size. This product left them feeling better than new because of the lanolin, and it didn't fade or bleed the colors. I use the same method on my wool blankets. I will never be without it.
